We've gotta look at the evidence given to us in the movies, because that's what we're discussing here.
In the original airing of Return of the Jedi we are shown Anakin Skywalker as portrayed by Sebastian Shaw as a middle-aged man with no scars. We also see Obi-wan and Yoda in advanced ages. Therefore we must assume that ghosts project an image of their physical self at the age of their death but without the damage done to their bodies. That is what's shown in the film. Full stop.

Years later George makes the prequels and decides to retcon Shaw and turn him into Christensen, but whatever he hoped to fix he just made more confusing, because now poor fans have to come up with a whole bunch of presuppositions to make sense of his change, like that they can change their form based upon their will, or that it's all some mental projection, or that scars must be shown for some reason. None of which is actually supported by any evidence, it's just the only way to make sense of a retcon.

If you're looking for a movie that does a similar thing except well, its literally Boogie Nights. The basic structure and theme of that story is that you start out with something and you're good at it and you're "with it" so to say. Then things change and you're no longer with it and you have to deal with not being with it any more. Then maybe things come back around and you're with it again. Boogie Nights just uses the history of the porn industry as a general structure to tell you this but the implication of course is that it applies to life in general.

Babylon meanwhile just does it poorly and even rips off Boogie Nights to seemingly highlight the point. Hell I even think the masturbatory ending is literally a joke because Boogie Nights was about porn or something and that's something you literally masturbate too.

the squid version is naively optimistic. it imagines that in the face of a greater threat humanity would come together in opposition of it. its a threat to be conquered, a problem to be tackled. its a hopeful message in an otherwise cynical comic

the Dr manhattan bomb ending is much darker, and fits the tone of the comic a bit better. its a gun to humanities collective head with the triggerman saying "behave" and then fucking off to the shadows, and both Dr manhattan and veidt realize, probably very realistically, that if they were ever to take their finger off the trigger the nations would devolve back into bitter rivalry, so they needed an ever present threat, the gunman needs to be lurking in the shadows, humanity powerless to stop it.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The real reason the SQUID is in the original comic is because it was a major reference to the old Justice League comics from the 50s and 60s where in pretty much every issue the heroes would team up against a giant alien monster that came from another planet to conquer the world as well a reference to Lovecraft's horror stories. This is why you've the story pretty much being a creepy mystery where Rorschach and NiteOwl II goes around investing all the authors, artists, and so on that went missing.

The movie did away with the SQUID because it would split the story into two different things: the investigation on who killed the Comedian, which was the driving force of the narrative, and all these missing people. In a 12 issue comic you can do that but in a movie you've to keep things simple. So that means you can only focus on the Comedian stuff. That also meant that all the set ups where the team goes investigating all the missing people can't be done. Without that set up you can't do the SQUID.

Voight is smart enough to know that politicians would not just shrug their shoulders and leave America blameless and that's why it's a worse ending. It relies on Voight being both a cynic and an optimist at the same time as well as being both smart and retarded at the same time.

I don't have a very clear explanation. But the show often touches on the subject of the unconscious. Some of the severed had traumas that they just want to throw away. They got a severed job so that they can just zone out kind of and let their innie be the "functional adult". But they can't really make it disappear and innies still have to deal with it in their unconscious without even knowing what it is. And it's why their outies keep sending them back there. But they can't possibly deal with it, they don't have the memories. For them, it really is an unfathomable darkness that's just there.
In whatshisface's case, his outie is an artist that paints his trauma. His innie unconsciously associates it with dark goop. But then there seems to be some communication between the two where his outie paints stuff that traumatized his innie.
Maybe the hundreds of clones represent the hundreds of theories they all have about their outies (and the outside world, etc).
Anyway maybe there's more to it than that. The show has been brilliant so far and I'm pretty curious how they'll manage to make a sequel to that. Most likely not everything will turn out to have a clear explanation and just served an artistic purpose and that's OK I think.

>>180185561
Some fair points here, but if Rey is meant to be an audience insert, she cannot be as infallible as she was in TFA. Both for the sake of the film's narrative in and of itself, and the wider implications given what we already know about the Star Wars universe. She thwarts the grandson of the most powerful Jedi at every turn with little effort, meaning she must be "SOMEBODY" given Star Wars is obsessed with lineages. She rarely has to make any difficult decisions or concessions, making her unrelatable and unsympathetic. This leads to her being more of an, as you pointed out, mystery box than an actual character. "Who is she? Who is her father (and it must be a character we know!)" She SHOULD have been a nobody, but JJ made sure we wouldn't be given an actual protagonist by giving us the myriad scenes of her performing master-level feats within hours of leaving nu-Tatooine.

I partially agree with Snoke. He was underutilized. We don't necessarily need a drawn-out backstory, but the dynamic between him, Kylo and Hux could have been something. I think people were overly concerned about him being some legacy character, though. The Luke plotline makes little sense, and immediately sets him up as the coward people claim him to be in TLJ. Why does his sister and supposed best friend need to chase him across the galaxy? If he had a plan, wouldn't it at least be prudent to have the only other force user he knows be in on it? Finn had potential, but it was squandered the second they threw away is trauma for comic relief, which was almost immediately. He acts nothing like a military deserter (especially one who was groomed as a child).

The whole movie is just a waste of fucking time. It begins, it happens, it ends. It puts all the pressure on the later films to do anything interesting.

>If there actually is decent American beers, other countries won't get to experience them and start taking you guys seriously.
America is massive. Not just geographically (because so is Australia) but culturally, economically, etc. When you mention "decent American beers" or really anything, what you're actually talking about is something smaller and more local/regional. We can't just open a Publix in Canberra or sell Jones Green Apple soda in Sydney because those things don't even scale across the United States, much less the world. If Australia had a global culture, it would be shit too. Just look at how you (rightfully) tend to turn your nose up at Crocodile Dundee or Fosters. Meanwhile, Americans who REALLY like Coca-Cola don't even drink American Coke, we drink Mexican bottled Coca-Cola because it's still bottled with cane sugar. But that's regional and limited in supply. It's really as simple as the good things tend to burn more local.

>>180181683
It's genuinely amazing.
Some of the most striking visuals I have ever seen, the color pallette is beautiful, the colors translate that humid tropical / island feeling spot on.Like to the point that you might start sweating yourself. Obviously inspired by late Fassbinder, notably his last film Querelle but the effect is different.
The thriller element is present but put on the background in a way similar to Antonioni's Blow Up while the center of the film is usual meditative, observational Serra thing. This is a striking contrast especially since the story unfolding in the background has dark, apocalyptic implications which are very much dissonant to the overall tone.
Spoilers if you didn't see didn't get it:
The implication the film makes is that the French will inevitably nuke the island with all it's inhabitants .

>>180185045
People who demanded censorship because they were personally offended were rightfully mocked.
Movies like PCU launched the careers of people like Jeremy Piven and Jon Favreau.
X-Files and Babylon 5 introduced the concept of 'story arc' television and it was glorious (X Files in particular as its development of the concept was required to cover up that Gillian Anderson got knocked up by a crew member).
If you lived in the boonies there was probably a video place nearby where you could hire Star Trek: TNG, and if the owner was a superstar he often had obscure stuff to hand.
I remember being a first year college kid at a rural university and approaching the local hole-in-the-wall video place to hire some 'bad taste' movies for a movie night and being offered zoo porn. The dingy little shop has since been replaced with this soulless monstrosity, more's the pity.
All in all it was a much more vibrant and interesting time to be alive.

>>180192276
This is a complex issue. If she were even a little older, it would be clear cut that yes, he's a fucking simp. But the fact that she's a young teenager adds a layer, because many men would have taken a boy that age in a bad situation under their wing and helped him, too.
But Travis had a lot of sexual frustration. He clearly wanted to fuck this kid, but couldn't bring himself to actually do it and hated the people who could.
But at the same time, he had a real chance with a grown woman who was far more attractive and threw it away. And despite being obviously mentally ill and tempted toward that direction, he did not go off on the other man in the woman's he was much more obviously interested life. Instead, he focused his self-destructiveness and used it to help the young girl instead with no impure motive at all.
So no, in the end I don't think he did what he did due to simpery. I think he wanted his life, and his death, to mean something, and so he did the best thing he could think to do with his dark impulses. He did it on his own terms knowing it wouldn't end with him dick-deep in jailbait. I don't think that's simping at all at that point.

posts.com:
I got memed into watching Tokyo Drift by some friends and passive absorption of car culture.
Thought it was going to at least be a little fun.
It really wasn't.
A lot of the car stunts weren't particularly well shot, and there (shockingly) weren't even that many to begin with.
Wasn't even very fun to point and laugh at the movie with friends. A terrible slog in nearly every sense.
I can think of one particularly good car action scene and one mildly humorous moment, but it's all wrapped in soulless, boring shit.
The inadvertent but true purpose of the movie is to convince the masses that car enthusiasts are utterly vapid, insecure morons.

I am deeply offended by its existence.

Now I'm getting told "Oh no, no, the earlier ones are more fun! You need to watch those!"
I might.
Maybe I am a moron.
